intro: Dalea canescens, commonly known as the plains false indigo, is a perennial herb native to the central and western United States. It is characterized by its slender, erect stems and clusters of small, pale blue to lavender flowers. The plant has bipinnate leaves that are covered in fine, white hairs, giving it a silvery appearance. It thrives in dry, sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in prairie and steppe habitats. Dalea canescens is valued for its ornamental appeal and its role in supporting local pollinators.
